The Median Voter Theorem is a concept in voting theory that states that in a majority voting system, the alternative preferred by the median voter will always defeat any other alternative in a pairwise majority vote. This theorem is based on the assumption that voters have single-peaked preferences, meaning that their preferences are ordered along a single dimension.

To understand the Median Voter Theorem, lets break it down. Suppose we have a group of voters with individual preferences for different alternatives. The median voter is the one whose preference lies exactly in the middle of the sorted list of individual preferences. 

Now, lets consider an alternative, X_t, that lies to the right of the median voters favorite alternative, X_m. In this case, X_m is preferred by all voters whose peak preference lies on X_m or to its left. This is because X_m is closer to the peak of their preferences compared to X_t. Therefore, everyone in the first (k1)/2 positions, where k is the number of voters, prefers X_m to X_t. Since this is a strict majority of the voters, X_m defeats X_t in a pairwise majority vote.

The Median Voter Theorem guarantees that the median individual favorite will always gather a majority of support against any other alternative because it lies between each voters respective favorite and X_t. This property allows us to use majority rule among all pairs to produce a complete and transitive group ranking.

To find more information about the Median Voter Theorem, you can refer to Chapter 23.6 of the educational resource you mentioned. This chapter specifically discusses single-peaked preferences and the Median Voter Theorem. You can find detailed explanations, examples, and further insights in this chapter.
